Award.AwardTitle: GOALI/Collaborative Research: Process Development across Alloy Systems for Powder Bed Additive Manufacturing

Division.LongName: Div Of Civil, Mechanical, & Manufact Inn

Award.AbstractNarration:
This collaborative Grant Opportunities for Academic Liaison with Industry (GOALI) project will apply fundamental research to the problem of controlling melt pool dimensions and microstructure for electron beam direct metal powder bed additive manufacturing processes. Specifically, it will address how to transfer control methods developed for one material system to another material system in a way that reduces costly and time-consuming experimentation. To accomplish this, this project will develop a first-of-its kind modeling-based process mapping approach for application across different materials used in direct metal powder bed additive manufacturing processes. Process mapping methods will be applied to experiments performed on multiple metal alloys using additive manufacturing equipment available to the investigators.

Direct metal additive manufacturing is of great interest to the aerospace, medical implant, and other industries. It offers the promise of decreased manufacturing cost, substantial reductions in the amount of material used to build a component, and the ability to fabricate structures not realizable by conventional manufacturing methods. Two barriers to widespread use of direct metal additive manufacturing in the aerospace and other industries are (1) the lack of a platform for transferring process knowledge (e.g. how to build shapes) from one metal alloy system to another; and (2) limited knowledge about controlling microstructure and mechanical properties for any alloy system. These barriers lead to expensive, costly experimentation in applying additive manufacturing to new material systems and the inability to certify mechanical strength in fabricated components. This project will overcome both of these barriers through research accomplished by a team that includes academic investigators from three universities (North Carolina State, Carnegie Mellon and Wright State) and a collaborator from the aerospace industry currently working to integrate direct metal additive manufacturing into component production (Pratt & Whitney).

POR.DRECONTENT:
This collaborative research project has successfully extended process mapping approaches developed by the PIs to better understand the relationships between melt pool geometry and resulting microstructure in beam-based metal additive manufacturing (AM) processes. Process mapping involves the representation of experimental and/or computational model results for melt pool geometry and/or microstructural features in power-velocity space. This allows AM process developers to better understand how changes in process variables affect melt pool geometry and resulting microstructure for a particular material system and additive manufacturing process. These process mapping approaches were initially developed for wire-feed electron beam melting (EBM) processes and were restricted to the Ti-6Al-4V material system. The current project has extended the process mapping approach to powder bed additive manufacturing processes across multiple alloy systems.  

The specific outcomes of this work have included the following:

1) The successful adaptation of process mapping procedures previously developed for Ti-6Al-4V for application to nickel-based super alloys (IN718 and IN625).

2) The development and validation of closed-form microstructural process map equations for investigating trends in solidification microstructure with changes in process variables. 

3) The development of a nondimensional microstructural process map applicable to any alloy system and beam-based additive manufacturing process.

In addition to providing fundamental insight into the relationships between process variables, thermophysical properties and solidification behavior in beam-based additive manufacturing processes, the results of this work are of direct and immediate use to process developers working to advance the more widespread use of AM processes in aerospace and other industries.  The graduate and undergraduate students involved in this project have developed a combined manufacturing, solid mechanics, heat transfer and materials background that will make them highly valuable in industry and academics.  In addition, students involved in this project have benefited greatly from their interactions with industrial and government researchers.  The graduation of these students will address the growing industry need for multidisciplinary engineers, who are comfortable working in teams of diverse technical background.


Last Modified: 08/10/2018
Modified by: Nathan Klingbeil
